name: Marcus Garvey
summary: Founder of the Universal Negro Improvement Association (UNIA) and a leading proponent of Black Nationalism and the 'Back-to-Africa' movement in the early 20th century.
detail: Marcus Garvey's movement, known as Garveyism, was the largest mass movement in Black history, stressing economic self-sufficiency, racial pride, and the eventual repatriation of Black people to Africa. His organization, the UNIA, established businesses like the Black Star Line shipping company, making his vision highly practical and widespread.
sources: The Philosophy and Opinions of Marcus Garvey (Collection)

name: W.E.B. Du Bois
summary: Sociologist, historian, and Pan-African activist. He was a co-founder of the NAACP and organized a series of Pan-African Congresses, advocating for political and social equality.
detail: Du Bois is famous for his concept of 'double consciousness,' the internal conflict experienced by Black Americans who must view themselves through the eyes of a society that despises them. He represented a more intellectual, gradual approach to liberation compared to Garvey's mass movement.

name: Pan-Africanism
summary: A worldwide intellectual and political movement aimed at strengthening solidarity between all people of African descent, advocating for a united and independent Africa.
detail: The movement took its earliest political form in the Pan-African Congresses organized by Du Bois. Later, it became the foundation for the independence movements across the continent, culminating in the establishment of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) in 1963.
sources: Africa and Unity: The Evolution of Pan-Africanism by Kwame Nkrumah

name: Kwame Nkrumah
summary: First Prime Minister and President of Ghana. A leading figure in the anti-colonial movement, Nkrumah was a fierce champion of Pan-Africanism, calling for a 'United States of Africa.'
detail: Nkrumah studied and worked closely with George Padmore and was heavily influenced by the ideas of Garvey and Du Bois, eventually welcoming Du Bois to Ghana late in his life. His political philosophy, Consciencism, aimed to integrate African and Western thought.
sources: Neo-Colonialism, the Last Stage of Imperialism (Book)

name: Thomas Sankara
summary: The 'Upright Man' and revolutionary President of Burkina Faso who championed African self-reliance.
detail: Sankara renamed his country from Upper Volta to Burkina Faso ('Land of Upright People'). He launched massive programs for vaccinations, tree planting to stop desertification, and promoted domestic product consumption to end dependency on foreign aid.

name: Claudia Jones
summary: Trinidadian-born journalist and activist who founded the first major Black newspaper in the UK.
detail: Known as the 'Mother of Black Consciousness in Britain,' she founded the West Indian Gazette and was a driving force behind the creation of the Notting Hill Carnival as a way to unite the community through culture after racial attacks.
sources: Left of Karl Marx by Carole Boyce Davies

name: Frantz Fanon
summary: Psychiatrist and revolutionary from Martinique whose work focused on the psychology of colonialism.
detail: His seminal works, The Wretched of the Earth and Black Skin, White Masks, remain foundational texts for understanding the mental and physical effects of colonial oppression and the necessity of liberation.

name: Steve Biko
summary: Anti-apartheid activist and the father of the Black Consciousness Movement in South Africa.
detail: Biko famously stated, 'The most potent weapon in the hands of the oppressor is the mind of the oppressed.' He empowered Black South Africans to take pride in their identity and lead their own liberation.

name: Negritude Movement
summary: A literary and ideological movement led by Francophone Black intellectuals to celebrate African culture.
detail: Born in Paris, the movement sought to reclaim African values and identity from French colonial assimilation. It used poetry and literature to argue for the inherent dignity of Black civilizations.

name: Black Panther Party
summary: A revolutionary organization in the US that advocated for self-defense and community social programs.
detail: While famous for their armed patrols, the Panthers also created 'Survival Programs' like free medical clinics and breakfast for children, embodying the principle of community care and self-determination.
sources: The Black Panther Party: A Graphic Novel History

name: The Haitian Revolution
summary: The only successful slave revolt in history that led to the founding of a free Black state.
detail: Haiti's victory over France, England, and Spain sent shockwaves through the world and served as a beacon of hope for enslaved and colonized people for centuries to come.

name: Amy Jacques Garvey
summary: Journalist and activist who was a key leader of the UNIA and the primary editor of Garveyism's core texts.
detail: While Marcus Garvey was imprisoned, Amy Jacques Garvey led the UNIA, managed its finances, and published 'The Philosophy and Opinions of Marcus Garvey.' She was a pioneer of 'Black Cross Nurses' and integrated feminist ideals into the Black Nationalist movement.
sources: The Philosophy and Opinions of Marcus Garvey (Editor)

name: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela
summary: South African anti-apartheid activist and politician known as the 'Mother of the Nation'.
detail: Winnie was a fierce and uncompromising leader of the struggle against Apartheid. Despite constant harassment, house arrest, and imprisonment by the state, she remained a symbol of resistance and a voice for the marginalized when many others were silenced.

name: Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti
summary: Nigerian educator, political campaigner, and women's rights activist often called the 'Mother of Africa'.
detail: A powerhouse in Nigerian politics, she led thousands of women in protests against unfair taxes and for women's voting rights. She was the first woman in Nigeria to drive a car and was a lifelong advocate for African socialism and independence.
sources: For Women and the Nation: Funmilayo Ransome-Kuti of Nigeria (Book)

name: Wangari Maathai
summary: Kenyan environmental and political activist; the first African woman to win the Nobel Peace Prize.
detail: She founded the Green Belt Movement, which combined community development and environmental conservation by teaching women to plant trees. She linked ecological health to democratic governance and peace, famously saying, 'You cannot protect the environment unless you empower people.'

name: Miriam Makeba
summary: South African singer and civil rights activist known worldwide as 'Mama Africa'.
detail: Makeba used her global fame to testify against Apartheid at the United Nations. She lived in exile for over 30 years, often staying in Guinea as a guest of Sékou Touré. Her music was a bridge that connected the African continent to the diaspora in the US and beyond.
